applications take a look at the link it'll be shared at the end
so container basically very quickly is a standardized unit of software that packages up code all of its dependencies so the
application runs quickly reliably from one computing environment to another so basically you you can
imagine a container being a giant zip file that contains your source code of course
but also all the runtimes all the configurations that are needed so if you have a node.js that you want
to uh to deploy you will package up um all of your you know javascript files
but you will also package up npm and you'll package up node.js and you'll package up um basically a version of linux that has
all of those dependencies or runtimes installed and that's what you will ship so by
using a container like that you make sure that the environment is very very reliable you don't have those
issues where you know you're trying to deploy something on a server that runs node 8 because they never upgraded or any of those problems
so it really makes it a lot more reliable to send those units
it's also a disposable unit so that's very important to keep in mind once it is completed it destroys itself
along with all dependencies so if you have a database for example that runs in a container once you stop that container it will
destroy all the information so that can be good and that could be great for
things such as testing because it just you know you can put in as much garbage in your database and you just destroy it
once you're done and you start from scratch next time but when you're trying to save that data uh not as convenient so you'll need a
few tricks to help you with that when running locally you can mount a volume a local volume with the data but
that's or you can use things such as kubernetes which is what i've used here
so to use a container docker run is the way to start those containers and yeah you can just map some port call
your image and off it goes it is ready to run you can create your own images so you can use an image such as
node 14 where was it right here or node 12 in this case or you can create your own by using a docker file
and that will create your own own image that you can then deploy on servers so you can build that image and
push it to a repository or registry so now that i had all those micro
services i needed a way for them to communicate to each other my first my first reflex was to use a
rest api for each one of those services i wanted to use a rest api but it quickly became really complex and
i was trying to figure out like okay well maybe i could use some sort of way instead of using rest apis to
for them to communicate through a central point and i was trying to build one rest apis where all the other

you can have more than one uh consumer that will extract those messages and that was very convenient because

containers are running at any given time so if it sees that one of your containers stopped it will just
start a new one if you need to scale it up because you've got a good amount of
data coming in and you need to process it a little bit faster just like i've shown you earlier while you can easily scale it up and
